awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Exploring the Evolution of Shifts in Reproductive Function in Hermaphroditic Fishes Using Gene Coexpression Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Genes and gene pathways responsible for sexual development are highly conserved across animal taxa; organisms as different as humans, fishes, and flies share some of the same basic building blocks for determining if an individual develops as a female or a male. This study will investigate the genetic basis of sexual development in two species of fish. In most animals, sex is predetermined by genetics, established during development, and is fixed for life. This pattern is not true, however, for numerous fish species that exhibit the remarkable ability to change their functional sex (referred to as hermaphroditism). Individuals are neither female nor male and can shift between producing both sperm and eggs as adults. We know very little about the genetic bases of shifting sexual function. Understanding the ability of hermaphroditic fishes to produce new tissues for generating sperm and ova  throughout their lives could provide vital information for solving fertility issues in humans, who do not have this ability. In addition, based on the findings, the researchers will provide classroom material for elementary and middle school students.

Sequential hermaphroditism, the ability to transition between gamete types at some point in adult life, is a widespread strategy among teleost fishes. This study aims to understand the development, evolution and diversification of shifts in sexual function in the marine fish family Gobiidae. This family is an ideal system in which to explore both the evolution and development of sexual plasticity, as hermaphroditism has arisen independently as many as five times. The study will compare two species, Eviota epiphanes with Lythrypnus dalliI. Histological techniques will be used to generate a morphological time series of fish gonads as they transition from ova to sperm production and sequence the whole transcriptome (RNAseq) of brain and gonadal tissue as they transition. These data will be used to construct gene coexpression networks that will be compared between the two species. The results will provide insight into the gene regulatory pathways that govern the sex change process and be used to test for evolutionary conservation or change in those pathways.

por.por_cntn:
Sexual developmental processes are highly conserved across vertebrates. This means that the genes and gene pathways that are responsible for structuring an animal as male or female during development are often conserved across taxa. In the majority of vertebrate species the sexual function of the individual is established during embryogenesis. However, among some species, notably among teleosts, individuals can repeatedly shift sexual function between ova and sperm production. Our research focuses on an investigation of the genes responsible for such shifts in two serially hermaphroditic fish species in the family Gobiidae; Eviota epiphanes and Lythrypnus dalli. In both species adults are able to alternate repeatedly between ova and sperm production (i.e., serial hermaphroditism). Our aim was to identify and compare what genes are responsible for changes in sexual function in these two species to see if novel genes and/or gene pathways are associated with their serial hermaphroditism. The results of this study will elucidate whether the development of serial hermaphroditism in E. epiphanes and L. dalli is through conserved pathways for regulating sexual function in teleosts, or through the appearance of novel genes and/or regulatory pathways. In addition, the identification of genes and gene pathways involved in the repeated restructuring of the gonad to alternately produce ova and sperm within a single individual has the potential to make a significant contribution to the development of therapies for treating human fertility issues.

To obtain the necessary information to address the above question, we used RNASeq to capture all genes actively involved in transcription during transitions from producing eggs to producing sperm in the two focal species. Of the approximately 80,000 protein coding genes obtained, we were able to identify approximately 17,000 in each species. So far we have found the majority of the genes being expressed are the same for both species, but the timing and levels of expression differ considerably. When we look more closely at genes that have been identified as important to the normal development of sexual function in non-sex changing teleost species, we find many of these genes also being expressed during sexual transition in our two subject species. In some cases patterns of expression are as expected, based on other vertebrate models. We do, however, additionally see expression patterns for several regulatory genes that we would not expect, based on other animal models. Differences we have found in the expression patterns between the two focal species indicates that while both are changing sex in a similar fashion in terms of their morphology, the genetic regulation of this process shows some differences. We are currently focusing on constructing gene coexpression networks with our data to characterize these differences further. In other vertebrate models coexpression networks have been found to closely mirror biological pathways. Using this same approach we hope to capture the biological pathway that leads to a functional transition in gamete production. Already with our network analyses we have identified several gene clusters that are enriched for genes known to be involved in sexual development in other vertebrate species. This work is ongoing.
